message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The blisters on the abdomen, anterior chest, and anterior and posterior aspects of the right upper extremity and right thigh suggest that these areas have been affected by 2nd-degree burns. The skin over the left thigh is not affected by burns, so it can be excluded from the calculation. A rough estimation of the affected body surface area can be done using the Rule of Nines, which divides the body into areas of 9%. Based on the description of the affected areas, the closest approximation would be 36% (9% for each arm, 18% for the trunk, 9% for each leg).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In this case, the Rule of Nines can be used to estimate the body surface area affected by burns. According to the rule, the anterior and posterior aspects of each upper limb are 9% each, the anterior and posterior aspects of each lower limb are 18% each, the anterior trunk is 18%, the posterior trunk is 18%, the head is 9%, and the perineum is 1%. Therefore, in this case, the affected areas on the abdomen, anterior chest, right upper extremity, and right thigh add up to a total of 36%.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rule of nines is used to estimate the total body surface area affected by burns. According to this rule, the anterior chest and abdomen each represent 18% of the total body surface area, the right arm and leg each represent 9%, the left arm and leg each represent 9%, and the back represents 18%. Based on this, the total body surface area affected by the burns in the patient is 9 + 9 + 18 = 36%. Option D is the closest approximation.

We refer to guidelines on the estimation of burn size for help. The Rule of Nines estimates the body surface area of burns. According to this method, the anterior trunk accounts for 18% and the posterior trunk accounts for 18% of the body surface area. Each upper limb accounts for 9%, and each lower limb accounts for 18%. Therefore, the right upper limb and thigh (9% + 18% = 27%) and the anterior chest and abdomen (18%) together add up to 45%. Since only some areas on the right side are affected and the left side is unaffected, we can estimate that approximately half of the affected area is burned, making it closer to 36% (45% ÷ 2 = 22.5% for the affected area, plus 18% for the unaffected area on the left side). However, the exact percentage cannot be determined without a thorough examination of the patient, so choice (D) is the closest approximation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the location and extent of the burns, we can estimate that the affected body surface area is approximately 36%. This can be calculated using the rule of nines, which assigns a percentage to different body regions based on their size. The abdomen and anterior chest each account for 9% of total body surface area, while each upper extremity accounts for 9% and each lower extremity accounts for 18%.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rule of nines estimates the body surface area affected by burns in adults. According to the rule of nines, the anterior chest, abdomen, right upper extremity, and right thigh each represent 9% of the total body surface area (36% in total). The left thigh represents another 9%, but it is described as having 1st-degree burns with quick capillary refill, meaning it is not included in the calculation for 2nd-degree burns.

We refer to the Rule of Nines for estimating the body surface area affected by burns. According to the rule, the anterior trunk, posterior trunk, and both upper extremities each make up 9% of body surface area, and each lower extremity makes up 18%. Therefore, in this case, the affected area is:
Abdomen: 9%
Anterior chest: 9%
Right upper extremity: 9%
Right thigh: 18%
Total affected area: 45%
However, since the blisters on the left thigh are classified as 1st-degree burns (erythema and quick capillary refill), they are not factored into the calculation of affected body surface area. Therefore, the total affected area is actually:
Abdomen: 9%
Anterior chest: 9%
Right upper extremity: 9%
Right thigh: 18%
Left thigh (1st-degree): 9%
Total affected area: 36%

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has second-degree burns, and we need to approximate the body surface area affected. The rule of nines estimates the percentage of the total body surface area affected in adults: each arm is 9%, the head is 9%, the torso is 36%, each leg is 18%. The blisters and skin changes are present in the anterior chest, abdomen, right upper extremity, and right thigh, which add up to 36% (9% + 9% + 18%). Therefore, the answer is (D).

We refer to the rule of nines for burns to determine the approximate percentage of body surface area affected. The abdomen and anterior chest each account for 9% and each upper extremity accounts for 9%, the right thigh accounts for 9%, and the left thigh accounts for 18%. Adding these up gives a total of 54%. However, the question specifies that only the right upper extremity and right thigh have second-degree burns, while the left thigh appears to have first-degree burns. Therefore, we subtract the percentage of the left thigh (which is 18%) from the total body surface area affected, giving us 54% - 18% = 36%. Therefore, the answer is (D), 36%.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a patch of burn on the left thigh, which suggests that only one limb is affected by the burn. Thus, we can estimate the body surface area (BSA) using the rule of nines, where each arm accounts for 4.5%, the anterior chest and abdomen each account for 18%, and each leg accounts for 9%. Adding up the affected areas, we get a BSA of 36% (18% from the chest and abdomen, 9% from each arm, and 36% from the right thigh). Therefore, the answer is (D).
